Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms(CSDM) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Jussi Eloranta of California State University at Northridge together with his undergraduate and graduate students, will study the interaction of atomic and molecular species with superfluid helium through optical spectroscopy based methods. Superfluid helium is an exceptional solvent with unique properties (e.g., vanishing viscosity, super-thermal conductivity, and liquid phase down to 0 K), which allow for fast energy dissipation, free diffusion of atoms and molecules, and minimization of thermal effects. Atomic and molecular species to be studied include copper and boron atoms and their dimers, as well as highly fluorescent molecules such as tetracene and glyoxal. The atomic species are expected to be useful for studying the superfluid properties of the liquid on the nanometer scale. Conversely, the surrounding superfluid liquid can also be used to probe the electronic properties of the solvated species.


The long-range goal of this project is to understand how the unusual solvent effects, such as solvent layer guiding and vortex alignment of atomic orbitals, can be used to alter the way chemical reactions proceed. This may result in chemical reactions following paths that would normally be suppressed at elevated temperatures. Examples of possible applications include preparation of novel molecular structures, synthesizing high-energy materials and fuels, and controlling chemical reactions at low temperatures ("field guided molecular synthesis"). Students working with Professor Eloranta will gain skills related to optics, lasers, vacuum technology, and electronics as well as theoretical tools required to solve quantum mechanical problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merits: This research concentrates on the study of atomic and molecular impurities in superfluid 4He. Such impurities form either snowball or bubble states in the liquid where the former corresponds to a pileup of liquid around the impurity with well defined surrounding solvent shells and the latter to a void created by the repulsive Pauli exchange interaction with ground state helium atoms. As superfluid helium remains liquid down to 0 K, it offers a unique environment for studying 1) solvation effects and their role in chemical reactions, 2) the superfluid response at atomic scales, 3) the formation of exotic chemical species and 4) the time-dependent impurity - superfluid response by using spectroscopic tools. Our group has recently concentrated on both fundamental experimental and theoretical work that is necessary for studying the aforementioned phenomena. The experimental work has demonstrated that the traditional laser ablation method of metal targets immersed in superfluid helium produces long-lasting macroscopic size gas bubbles with an internal temperature much higher than the bulk and is accompanied by emission of an intense shock wave. Such high density gas environment is ideal for producing large metal clusters but it is unsuitable for implanting isolated atomic species into the superfluid. We have developed a new approach based on a free-standing superfluid helium fountain where the impurities can be created in the gas phase and subsequently introduced into the fountain. Real-time spectroscopic imaging of metal atoms and dimers shows that their thermalization process is followed by a slow diffusive motion towards the fountain surface and finally the impurity - fountain collision event takes place. These experiments have outlined a new technique to introduce impurities into superfluid helium and provided a way to visualize how impurities interact with superfluid helium surface. Our recent theoretical work on excited state helium atoms, noble gas clusters and fluorine atoms in superfluid helium have elucidated the role of superfluid helium in the formation of quantum gels and established a direct link between the spectroscopic line shifts and the impurity - bath interaction.

Broader impacts: This research contributes to the following important areas in chemistry and physics: (I) high-resolution molecular spectroscopy at low temperatures, (II) experimental characterization of superfluid 4He on molecular scales under confinement, (III) non-polar solvation of atoms and molecules, (IV) preparation of novel molecular structures by using the special properties of the quantum liquid (e.g., free diffusion at very low temperatures and solvent/vortex guiding schemes), and (V) development of theoretical models for describing time-dependent phenomena in superfluid 4He. Research is an important part of our undergraduate training; students integrate their classroom knowledge with problem solving in an environment without a rigid learning structure. Undergraduate students are required to carry out research as a part of their degree. Our M.S. level chemistry graduate program is thesis based, which requires students to carry out semi-independent research. The current research proposal contributes to the physical chemistry section of our program. The practical skills obtained by students include vacuum and low temperature techniques, optics, lasers,
electronics, basic machining and computer programming. To further improve our program, I have continued to develop open lecture note materials and improve our student laboratory.
